questions.question: Which one of the following statements is correct for plain carbon steels?

options.A: The only phases that can form in plain carbon steels are those that appear on the Fe-Fe3C phase diagram.
options.B: The Fe-Fe3C phase diagram cannot be used to predict the phases that are present in a steel if it contains a high number of vacancy defects.
options.C: The Fe-Fe3C phase diagram can be used to predict whether martensite is likely to form in a steel or not.
options.D: Constant cooling transformation (CCT) diagrams can be used to predict the phases that will form when austenite is cooled to ambient temperature at a constant rate.
options.E: The Fe-Fe3C phase diagram is useful for determining the ductile-to-brittle transition temperature.

questions.question: Which one of the following statements is correct for ferrite in plain carbon steels?

options.A: Ferrite is a phase that is not stable at ambient temperature
options.B: Ferrite will transform to martensite when it is cooled rapidly.
options.C: Ferrite will exhibit a ductile-to-brittle transition.
options.D: Ferrite forms when grains of austenite undergo a shear transformation.
options.E: Ferrite is a face-centred cubic form of iron that forms when a steel is cooled slowly from elevated temperatures.

questions.question: Which one of the following statements is correct in relation to pearlite in steels?

options.A: Pearlite is a single phase comprising a mixture of ferrite and cementite
options.B: An increase in the proportion of pearlite in the microstructure, and a reduction in the proportion of ferrite, will lead to increased toughness for the steel.
options.C: The spacing of the lamellae (i.e. alternating layers) of ferrite and cementite in pearlite can change depending on the rate at which austenite is cooled.
options.D: When austenite is cooled, pearlite can only form if some ferrite forms beforehand.
options.E: Pearlite refers to a mixture of ferrite and cementite that forms via a shear transformation.

questions.question: Which one of the following is correct for normalised (slow-cooled) steels?

options.A: An increase in the proportion of pearlite will lead to an increase in strength.
options.B: Normalised steels do not exhibit a ductile-to-brittle transition.
options.C: Pearlite has a face-centred cubic (FCC) crystal structure.
options.D: It is never possible to achieve a microstructure comprising 100% pearlite.
options.E: An increase in the proportion of pearlite will lead to an increase in toughness.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a quench and temper (QT) heat treatment?

options.A: To achieve a martensitic microstructure in the steel
options.B: To reduce the ductile-to-brittle transition temperature.
options.C: To avoid the excessive oxidation that occurs during air cooling of steels
options.D: To eliminate the formation of cementite.
options.E: To produce a steel with a higher strength than can be achieved through slow cooling from the austenitic state, while retaining sufficient toughness.

questions.question: Which one of the following is correct for the austenitisation step in QT heat  treatments?

options.A: Austenite has a body-centred cubic (BCC) crystal structure.
options.B: It is important to achieve a fully austenitic microstructure in this step to ensure that the chemical composition is uniform throughout the steel.
options.C: Austenite is a phase that does not have any grain boundaries
options.D: The formation of austenite promotes the formation of fine carbides throughout the microstructure.
options.E: Austenitising is carried out to eliminate the ductile-to-brittle transition in steels.

questions.question: Which one of the following is correct for the quenching step in QT heat treatments?

options.A: The purpose of quenching is to retain an austenitic microstructure at ambient temperature.
options.B: Martensite refers to a microstructure that forms when the rate of atomic  diffusion is very high.
options.C: Martensite is a phase containing a uniform distribution on fine carbides
options.D: Martensite can only form in steels that have a low toughness.
options.E: Water quenching can generate internal stresses that are large enough to cause “quench cracking” in some steels

questions.question: Which one of the following statements is correct for the tempering of steels?

options.A: The purpose of tempering is to prevent atomic diffusion in the steel.
options.B: Tempering can result in the formation of pearlite.
options.C: The purpose of tempering is to restore strength through a reversal of the martensitic shear transformation
options.D: Tempering is carried out to increase the toughness of the steel.
options.E: The purpose of tempering is to avoid martensite transforming into pearlite.

questions.question: Which one of the following statements is correct in relation to the alloying of steels?

options.A: Substitutional alloying elements can only be present in a steel if there are vacancies in the crystal lattice
options.B: Substitutional alloying elements are added to prevent the formation of martensite when quenching thick sections of steel.
options.C: When austenite is cooled, the presence of substitutional alloying elements acts  to retard time-dependent transformations to ferrite, pearlite and bainite
options.D: Substitutional alloying elements are added to a steel to reduce the likelihood  of cracking during quenching
options.E: Substitutional alloying elements are added to avoid the need for tempering  after a quenching operation.

questions.question: Which one of the following statements is correct for fusion welded joints in steels?.

options.A: A high carbon equivalent value for a steel would indicate that there is significant potential for cracking to occur when a joint cools after welding.
options.B: The carbon equivalent value can be used to calculate the width of the heataffected zone (HAZ) for a welded joint.
options.C: A high carbon equivalent value for a steel would suggest that it is not necessary to preheat the joint prior to welding.
options.D: A high carbon equivalent value indicates that a steel is unlikely to be at risk of brittle fracture after welding.
options.E: The carbon equivalent value can be used to calculate a suitable hold temperature for a post-weld heat treatment operation.
